sections.content: Only 32% of Ghanaians are considered financially literate, despite 96% having access to financial services.

source.label: Ministry of Finance Ghana — FLEC Launch 2024

sections.content: A budget is a plan for your money. It tells your money where to go instead of wondering where it went. With a budget, you spend on what matters and save for the future.
Why Budget?
Control: You decide where your money goes — not habit or impulse. Once you have a budget, you spend with intention and save more easily.
Budgeting reduces money stress, helps you reach goals like building an emergency fund, starting a business, or paying school fees — and keeps you out of debt.
The Basics
Your income is what you earn. Your expenses are what you spend. A budget balances the two.

sections.title: Kofi's Simple Budget
sections.content: Kofi earns GHS 2,400/month net. He spends GHS 1,200 on needs, GHS 600 on wants, and saves GHS 600. Income (GHS 2,400) − Expenses (GHS 1,800) = Savings (GHS 600). His budget is balanced.
Step 1: Know Your Income
Write down all money you receive each month: salary or wages, side jobs, allowances, or any regular income. Use your net income — the amount after tax and deductions — if you are employed.
Step 2: List Your Expenses

sections.caption: Expense Categories
rows: Rent, food, transport, utilities, school fees

sections.content: Step 3: Compare and Adjust
Add up all your expenses. Compare the total to your income.
If expenses exceed income, you are going into debt. Cut wants first, then look for cheaper alternatives for needs. Do not cut savings entirely — even GHS 50 per month adds up.

sections.description: Use the Budget Builder to plan your income and expenses using the 50/30/20 rule as a starting point.

sections.content: Budgeting is the foundation of all other financial literacy skills. Users who create a budget are 3× more likely to have an emergency fund.

source.label: Bank of Ghana Financial Literacy Programme

sections.content: The 50/30/20 rule is a simple, proven method to split your monthly income into three buckets: Needs, Wants, and Savings.

sections.caption: The 50/30/20 Rule
rows: Entertainment, hobbies, eating out, new clothes

sections.content: Why It Works
Needs first: You cover essentials before anything else. Wants are allowed — so you can enjoy life without guilt. Savings are built-in before you spend on extras.
Example: Ama's Budget

sections.title: Ama's Monthly 50/30/20
sections.content:
Ama earns GHS 3,200/month net.
• Needs (50%): GHS 1,600 — rent GHS 800, food GHS 500, transport GHS 300
• Wants (30%): GHS 960 — eating out GHS 400, entertainment GHS 300, clothing GHS 260
• Savings (20%): GHS 640 — emergency fund GHS 320, T-Bill GHS 320
Is 50/30/20 Right for Ghana?
It is a guide, not a law. Life in Ghana often means adjusting the percentages:
Start with what you can. Even a 5% savings rate is better than zero. Increase by 1–2% each month until you reach 20%.
People who follow a spending plan — even a simple one — save an average of 18% more per year than those without one.

source.label: Bank of Ghana Financial Literacy Programme

sections.content: You cannot improve what you do not measure. Tracking your spending shows where your money really goes — and most people are surprised by what they find.
Studies show that people who track spending reduce unnecessary expenses by an average of 15% within the first month.

source.label: Bank of Ghana Financial Literacy Programme

sections.content: How to Track Your Spending
Categories That Add Up Fast
Small, frequent purchases are the biggest budget killers. Transport (trotro, Uber), airtime, data, and chop-bar meals can easily exceed 25% of income without feeling like it.

sections.title: Yaa's Hidden Spending
sections.content: Yaa earns GHS 1,800/month. She thought she spent GHS 200/month on food outside. After tracking for 2 weeks, she found she spent GHS 420 — chop bar lunches at GHS 15/day added up to GHS 315 alone. By packing lunch 3 days/week she saved GHS 180/month.
Review Weekly
Every week, total your spending by category and compare to your budget. Under budget? Put the extra into savings. Over budget? Cut that category next week.
Track for at least one full month. After that you will know your real spending patterns and can set a realistic budget that you can actually stick to.

sections.content: Financial fraud cost Ghanaian consumers an estimated GHS 200 million in 2023 across mobile money, investment, and banking scams.
Fraudsters are sophisticated and persistent. But every scam follows the same psychological patterns. Once you know them, you can spot and avoid them.
Universal Red Flags

sections.caption: The 5 Red Flags of Financial Fraud
rows: 'Act now or lose your money' — pressure to decide immediately
'Don't tell anyone' — isolation from trusted advice
High returns with no risk — promises of 20%+ monthly
Unknown caller or message offering a deal or prize
Asking you to pay to receive money or a prize

sections.content: Common Scam Types in Ghana
Investment Scams: Any scheme promising 20%+ monthly returns is almost certainly a Ponzi scheme or fraud. Only invest with SEC-Ghana licensed firms. Verify at sec.gov.gh.

sections.title: The 'Double Your Money' Scam
sections.content: Esi was approached on WhatsApp by someone promising to 'double any amount in 48 hours using forex trading.' She invested GHS 500. The operator sent her GHS 1,000 back — encouraging her to invest GHS 5,000. When she did, the operator disappeared. This is a classic advance-fee Ponzi: early returns are paid with later victims' money.
How to Protect Yourself

Verify before you trust: 1) Check investment firms at sec.gov.gh. 2) Confirm bank messages by calling the official number on the back of your card. 3) Never rush a financial decision. 4) Ask a trusted family member or financial advisor before investing.
Investment schemes must be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission Ghana (SEC). Operating an unregistered scheme is illegal under the Securities Industry Act, 2016 (Act 929).
If You Are Scammed

1. Contact your bank or mobile money provider immediately to reverse or freeze the transaction if possible.
2. Report to the Ghana Police Service CID Fraud Unit.
3. Report investment fraud to the Securities and Exchange Commission Ghana.
4. Warn friends and family — scammers reuse the same victims' contact lists.

sections.definition: A fraudulent investment scheme that pays returns to existing investors using money from new investors, rather than from genuine profit. Ponzi schemes inevitably collapse when new investor money runs out. They are illegal in Ghana under the Securities Industry Act 2016.

sections.content: As a user of financial services in Ghana, you have legal rights that protect you. Knowing these rights helps you get fair treatment and take action when something goes wrong.

Ghana's consumer financial protection framework includes the Banks and Specialised Deposit-Taking Institutions Act 2016 (Act 930), Payment Systems and Services Act 2019 (Act 987), and the Bank of Ghana's Consumer Protection Directives.
Your Key Rights

sections.caption: Financial Consumer Rights in Ghana
rows: Terms, fees, and interest rates must be disclosed before you sign or pay
No discrimination based on gender, religion, or location
Every regulated institution must have a complaints process
Your personal and financial data cannot be shared without consent
You can escalate unresolved complaints to the Bank of Ghana

sections.content: Where to Complain

Always keep records: save receipts, SMS confirmations, and screenshots. Note dates, amounts, and the names of agents or officers you speak with. This documentation is essential if you need to escalate.

sections.title: Kofi's Successful Complaint
sections.content: Kofi was charged twice for a bill payment. He: 1) Reported it to MTN customer care with the transaction reference. 2) MTN promised a refund within 5 days but nothing happened. 3) Kofi escalated to the Bank of Ghana Consumer Affairs helpline (0302 666 174). 4) BoG opened an inquiry. MTN refunded GHS 120 within 48 hours.
The Bank of Ghana resolved over 4,800 consumer complaints in 2023, recovering GHS 15 million for consumers. Most cases were resolved within 30 days of escalation.

sections.definition: A government body that insures deposits held at licensed banks in Ghana. If a bank fails, GDPC protects each depositor's balance up to GHS 20,000. Established under the Ghana Deposit Protection Act, 2016 (Act 931).

sections.content: Saving in Ghana spans from traditional susu groups to modern bank accounts. Understanding both helps you choose the right option for your goals and lifestyle.
What is Susu?

Susu is a rotating savings group (ROSCA) where members contribute a fixed amount regularly and take turns receiving the lump sum. It has been used in Ghana for generations and builds discipline through peer accountability.
When to Use Each

Use susu when you need a structured way to save without easy access to temptation. Use a bank when you want interest, safety, and flexibility. Many Ghanaians use both — susu for short-term goals, bank for emergency fund.

sections.title: Abena's Approach
sections.content: Abena saves GHS 100/week in a susu group for school fees (lump sum in December). She also keeps GHS 2,000 in a bank savings account for emergencies. Both serve different purposes.
In Ghana, over 60% of households have experienced a financial shock (medical bills, job loss, or emergency travel) in the past two years with no savings buffer.

source.label: Bank of Ghana Financial Stability Report

sections.content: An emergency fund is money set aside specifically for unexpected events. It is your financial safety net — the difference between a crisis and an inconvenience.
What Counts as an Emergency?
Why It Matters in Ghana

Without an emergency fund, most Ghanaians turn to high-cost borrowing: mobile loans, susu advances, or informal moneylenders — which can charge 30–100% annual interest. An emergency fund makes these unnecessary.
How Much Do You Need?
The target is 3 to 6 months of essential expenses. Start small — even GHS 500 is a meaningful buffer. Build it incrementally over time.

sections.title: Abena's Emergency Fund Goal
sections.content:
Abena's monthly essentials: rent GHS 600, food GHS 400, transport GHS 200 = GHS 1,200/month.
3-month target: GHS 3,600 | 6-month target: GHS 7,200
She saves GHS 300/month → reaches her 3-month fund in 12 months.
Where to Keep It
Keep 1–2 months of expenses in a separate, easily accessible account. Put the rest in a short-term T-Bill for better returns while maintaining a buffer.

sections.description: Use the Savings Goal Planner to calculate how long it will take to reach your target.

sections.content: The Ghana Revenue Authority (GRA) is Ghana's national tax authority. Every taxpayer — individuals, businesses, and organisations — must register with GRA and obtain a Tax Identification Number (TIN).
Key Points
Your TIN is required to open a bank account, register a business, obtain a passport, or clear goods at customs. Apply online at gra.gov.gh or visit any GRA office.

PAYE (Pay As You Earn) is Ghana's income tax system. Your employer deducts tax from your salary each month based on graduated bands and remits it to GRA. Understanding the bands helps you verify your payslip.
Key Points
Use the PAYE/SSNIT calculator in CediWise to estimate your take-home pay and understand how deductions work.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.

SSNIT manages Ghana's mandatory Tier 1 pension. Both you (5.5%) and your employer (13%) contribute from your gross salary. SSNIT provides a monthly pension from age 60, invalidity benefits, and survivor benefits.
Key Points
Your SSNIT number is for life. Keep your contribution records — they determine your pension amount at retirement.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.

GRA offers several tax reliefs that reduce your taxable income — and therefore your PAYE. Common reliefs include personal relief, child education relief, and disability relief. You must apply to benefit.
Key Points
Check the GRA website for the full list of reliefs and how to claim them. Many employees miss out because they never apply.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.

VAT (Value Added Tax) applies to most goods and services in Ghana at a unified rate. SME owners with turnover above GHS 200,000 per year must register for VAT with GRA and charge it on taxable supplies.
Key Points
VAT registration brings compliance obligations but also allows you to reclaim VAT on business inputs. Get professional advice before registering.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.
Every investment carries risk. Generally, higher potential returns come with higher risk. Understanding the risk-return spectrum helps you choose investments that match your goals and comfort level.
Key Points
T-Bills are low risk, low return. Shares are higher risk, higher potential return. Diversification — spreading your money across different assets — reduces overall risk.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.

Treasury Bills (T-Bills) are short-term government debt. The Bank of Ghana issues 91-day, 182-day, and 364-day T-Bills. You buy at a discount and receive face value at maturity — the difference is your return.
Key Points
T-Bills are among the safest investments in Ghana. Use the T-Bill Simulator in CediWise to estimate returns.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.

Government bonds are longer-term debt instruments (2 years or more) that pay regular coupon interest. Unlike T-Bills, bonds provide periodic income. The Government of Ghana issues bonds through the Bank of Ghana.
Key Points
Bonds are suitable for investors who want steady income and can lock away funds for several years.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.
Mutual funds pool money from many investors and invest in a mix of T-Bills, bonds, and equities. Licensed fund managers in Ghana (e.g. Databank, FirstBanC) offer funds regulated by the SEC.
Key Points
Always verify that a fund manager is licensed with SEC Ghana before investing. Unlicensed schemes are often fraud.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.
The Ghana Stock Exchange (GSE) is where shares of listed companies are bought and sold. Investing in shares means owning a part of the company. Returns come from price appreciation and dividends.
Key Points
You need a licensed stockbroker to buy shares on the GSE. Never invest through unlicensed individuals or WhatsApp groups.

Insurance protects you from financial loss — medical bills, vehicle damage, death, or property loss. In Ghana, insurance is regulated by the National Insurance Commission (NIC). Premiums are the regular payments you make.
Key Points
Verify any insurer with NIC before buying a policy. Common products include motor, health, life, and business insurance.

Ghana recorded over 650 million mobile money transactions in 2023, totalling more than GHS 1.2 trillion — the highest volume in West Africa.

source.label: Bank of Ghana Payment Systems Report 2023

sections.content: Mobile money has fundamentally changed how Ghanaians send, receive, save, and pay for things. You no longer need a bank account to access financial services.
Main Providers in Ghana
All mobile money providers in Ghana are licensed and regulated by the Bank of Ghana under the Payment Systems and Services Act, 2019 (Act 987). Your funds are protected by BoG regulations.
What You Can Do with Mobile Money

Mobile money wallets allow you to: send money to family and friends instantly, pay bills (ECG, Ghana Water, DSTV, school fees), buy airtime and data, pay for goods at shops and markets, save directly in your wallet, and access short-term mobile loans.
How to Get Started

sections.title: Registering for MoMo
sections.content:
1. Visit any MTN MoMo agent with your Ghana Card (or Voter ID).
2. The agent registers your number and creates your wallet.
3. Set your personal PIN — do not share it with anyone, including the agent.
4. Cash in by handing cash to the agent or transferring from your bank app.
5. You are ready to send, pay, and save.
Fees to Know
Fees change periodically. Always check the current fee schedule on your provider's USSD menu (*170# for MTN) or their official website before large transactions.

sections.definition: A digital account linked to your phone number that allows you to store, send, and receive money electronically. Regulated by the Bank of Ghana. Not the same as a bank account, but provides many of the same basic services.

source.label: Bank of Ghana — Mobile Money Guidelines

sections.content: Mobile money fraud losses in Ghana exceeded GHS 40 million in 2023. The Bank of Ghana received over 12,000 fraud complaints related to mobile money.
Mobile money is convenient, but it is also a target for fraudsters. Knowing the common scams and how to protect yourself is essential.
The Golden Rule
Your PIN and OTP are yours alone. No legitimate employee of MTN, Vodafone, AirtelTigo, or any bank will ever ask for your PIN or OTP. Ever. If anyone asks — it is a scam.
Common Scams in Ghana

sections.caption: Mobile Money Scam Types
rows: Caller hangs up; you call a premium-rate number
'You've won! Send GHS 50 to claim your prize.'
Ignore — real wins never require payment
Fake BoG/MTN agent asks for PIN/OTP by call or SMS
Hang up. Call official number to verify
Stranger asks you to receive then forward money
Refuse — you may be used for fraud
Scammer transfers your number to their SIM
Alert your provider immediately if SIM stops working

sections.title: How Abena Almost Lost GHS 2,000
sections.content: Abena received an SMS: 'Congratulations! You have won GHS 5,000 in the MTN Loyalty Draw. To claim, dial *170# and send GHS 100 as a processing fee to 024XXXXXXX.' She almost sent the money, but called her sister first who told her it was a scam. MTN confirmed they never charge fees to claim prizes.
If You Are Scammed

Act immediately: 1) Call your mobile money provider's fraud line (MTN: 0244300000, Vodafone: 100). 2) Change your PIN right away. 3) Report to the police if a large sum was lost. 4) Warn friends and family about the same scam.

Under the Electronic Transactions Act 2008 (Act 772), mobile money fraud is a criminal offence in Ghana. Perpetrators face fines and imprisonment. Report all fraud to your provider and, for large amounts, to the Ghana Police Service.

sections.definition: A temporary, single-use code sent to your phone via SMS to verify your identity during a transaction. It is valid for only a few minutes and should NEVER be shared with anyone.

source.label: Bank of Ghana — Consumer Protection Guidelines

sections.content: Mobile money wallets can hold savings, and some providers offer interest. Bank savings accounts also earn interest and are protected by GDPC. Compare access, interest rates, and safety before deciding.
Key Points
For emergency funds, keep 1–2 months in instant-access (MoMo or bank). Put the rest in a bank savings or short T-Bill for better returns.

Digital credit — loans via mobile money (e.g. MTN Qwick Loan) — is convenient but can be expensive. Interest rates of 8–15% per month are common. Borrow only what you can repay on time.
Key Points
Before taking digital credit, calculate the total repayment. A GHS 500 loan at 10%/month costs GHS 50 in interest if repaid in one month.

Mixing personal and business money is one of the biggest mistakes SME owners make. It leads to unclear profitability, tax problems, and personal liability if the business fails. Open a separate business account from day one.
Key Points
Use one account for business income and expenses only. Pay yourself a salary or draw, and keep personal spending separate.

Cash flow is the movement of money in and out of your business. Many profitable businesses fail because they run out of cash — they cannot pay suppliers or staff when payments are delayed. Track and forecast cash flow weekly.
Key Points
Use the Cash Flow Tool in CediWise to project when money comes in and when it goes out. Plan for slow months.

Pricing for profit means covering all your costs — materials, labour, overhead, and your time — plus a margin. Underpricing is a common SME mistake that leads to burnout and business failure.
Key Points
Calculate your cost per unit, add your desired margin, and test the market. It is easier to lower prices than to raise them.

Business credit — loans, overdrafts, or supplier credit — can help you grow. Banks and microfinance institutions offer SME loans. Understand interest rates, repayment terms, and collateral requirements before borrowing.
Key Points
Use the Loan Amortization calculator to see total repayment and monthly instalments. Compare offers from multiple lenders.

SMEs must comply with GRA requirements: register for TIN, file tax returns, and if turnover exceeds thresholds, register for VAT. Non-compliance leads to penalties and limits access to formal credit.
Key Points
Hire an accountant or use GRA's simplified schemes for small businesses. Compliance builds credibility with banks and partners.

Business insurance protects against losses from fire, theft, liability, or key person death. The National Insurance Commission (NIC) regulates insurers. Choose products that match your business risks.
Key Points
Start with essential cover: fire, theft, and public liability. Add key person insurance if the business depends on one or two people.

The earlier you start saving for retirement, the more time compound interest has to grow your money. Delaying by 10 years can mean half the retirement fund. Start with whatever you can afford.
Key Points
Even GHS 100/month in a Tier 3 pension from age 25 can grow to a meaningful sum by 60. The key is starting early.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.

SSNIT Tier 1 is mandatory. Tier 2 is your employer's occupational scheme. Maximising both means ensuring contributions are correct, understanding your benefit statement, and planning for the lump sum at retirement.
Key Points
Request your SSNIT statement annually. Check that your employer is remitting both your and their contributions on time.
This lesson is being expanded with full content. Check back for updates or use the Financial Glossary to explore related terms.
Tier 3 is a voluntary personal pension. You contribute extra beyond Tier 1 and 2, and get 16.5% tax relief on contributions. NPRA-licensed fund managers offer Tier 3 products.
Key Points
Tier 3 is ideal if you want to retire with more than SSNIT and Tier 2 will provide. The tax relief makes it attractive.

Beyond pensions, you can build retirement wealth through T-Bills, bonds, property, or business. These 'non-pension' assets give you flexibility and diversification. Plan how they fit with your pension income.
Key Points
Diversify: do not put all retirement savings in one asset. T-Bills for stability, property for growth, business for income.

Succession planning ensures your assets go to the right people when you die. A will is the legal document that states your wishes. Without one, Ghana's intestacy laws determine who inherits — which may not match your intentions.
Key Points
Consult a lawyer to draft a will. Update it when your family or assets change. Keep a copy with someone you trust.

Your financial data — account numbers, PINs, transaction history — is valuable to fraudsters. Protect it: never share PINs or OTPs, use strong passwords, and be wary of phishing emails or fake websites.
Key Points
Banks and mobile money providers will never ask for your PIN or OTP by phone, email, or SMS. Anyone who does is a fraudster.
